the count of swabs, instruments, needles, blades and disposables in theatre

data.text: Contents
Introduction

All swabs, instruments including prosthetic templates, needles, blades and disposable equipment must be accounted for at all times during a surgical procedure, to prevent foreign body retention and subsequent injury to the patient. This policy includes all patients attending Main/Day Stay/ Ophthalmic/ Minor Ops and Maternity theatres.

If checks are not conducted according to this policy there is a risk of retention of a foreign body and subsequent harm to the patient undergoing a surgical procedure. This could result in a “Never Event” retained foreign body (see definitions).
A swab, instrument and needle count must be performed for all clinical invasive procedures.
Initial counts must be conducted by two members of staff, one of whom must be a registered practitioner:
1) Registered nurse / midwife
2) Registered Operating Department Practitioner

3) Diploma/NVQ Level 3 Theatre Practitioner qualified member of the theatre team (a qualified nurse or a qualified ODP, Diploma/NVQ level 3) the other team staff members may be a non-registered practitioners who haves attained the following awards:
Health (Perioperative Care Support) Level 3
Health (Obstetric Theatre Support) Level 3
Health (Anaesthetic/PACU Support) Level 3
HCA level 2/3 with theatre competencies completed.
Theatre Support Workers Level 2 with completed theatre competencies
Final Counts must be conducted by two members of staff one of whom must be a registered practitioner: Other team members who have attained the following awards:
Health (Perioperative Care Support) Level 3
Health (Obstetric Theatre Support) Level 3
Health (Anaesthetic/PACU Support) Level 3
HCA level 2/3 with theatre competencies completed
This is in accordance with National Guidance AFPP 2016
Purpose
The purpose of this document is to provide a clear and concise approach to ensure all swabs, instruments including prosthetic tem plates, needles, blades
and disposable equipment are accounted for at all times during a surgical procedure.
Definitions

table_items.text: Qualified nurse/ODP/HCA who assists the scrub practitioner in the operating theatre.
Disposable clips used in major laparoscopic surgery
Suture material without a needle attached.
Long needles for administrating local anaesthetic

NatSSIPs are intended to provide a skeleton for the production of Local Safety Standards for Invasive Procedures (LocSSIPs) that are created by multiprofessional clinical teams and their patients, They build on the WHO safer surgical checklist and human factors training
National Confidential Enquiry into Peri- operative Deaths/Immediate life threatening emergency

Never Events are serious incidents that are wholly preventable. Each Never Event type has the potential to cause serious patient harm or death. However, serious harm or death is not required to have happened as a result of a specific incident occurrence for that incident to be categorised as a Never Event.
National Institute for Clinical Health & Excellence
Small, round x-ray detectable gauze swabs
Piece of cotton that is tied around the swab packs

Retention of a foreign object in a patient after a surgical/invasive procedure. ‘Surgical/invasive procedure' includes interventional radiology, cardiology, interventions related to vaginal birth and Interventions performed outside of the surgical environment e.g. Central line placement in ward areas. ‘Foreign object' includes any items that should be subject to a formal counting /checking process at the commencement of the procedure and a counting /checking process before the procedure is completed (such as swabs, needles, instruments and guide wires) except where: Items are inserted any- time before the procedure that are not subject to the formal counting/checking process, with the intention of removing them during the procedure. Items that are known to be missing prior to the completion of the procedure and may be within the patient (e.g. screw fragments, drill bits) but where further action to locate and/or retrieve would be impossible or be more damaging than retention.
Bags used during laparoscopic cases to retrieve tissue

Before the patient leaves the operating theatre, all staff involved in the procedure must stop to confirm that they have completed the listed tasks on the laminated WHO Safer Surgical Checklist at sign out which includes the completion of all count of Swabs, Instruments, Needles, Blades and Disposables in Theatre
Slings that go around an artery/vein or organ
Used for skin preparation and are used with sponge holders
Nylon tapes used for isolating vessels
Gauze roll that can detected with an X-ray
Detachable disposable inserts for arterial clamps
Swabs that have a strip of material that is shown up in an X-ray

data.text: Duties
The Trust Board is collectively responsible for ensuring Southend University Hospital NHS Trust has robust and up to date procedural documents in place to govern and guide activities.

data.url: MSEPO-21143 Count of swabs, instruments, needles, blades and disposables in theatre.003.png

data.text: Theatre and Anaesthetics Division Committee is responsible for ensuring this policy is regularly up dated and reviewed.
Theatre Governance and Practice Groups are responsible for updating and reviewing this policy in line with national guidelines.
Chief Executive has the overall responsibility for ensuring that the MSE hospitals have robust and up to date procedural documents in place to govern and guide activities.

Director of Nursing is responsible for overseeing progress on all procedural documents and reviewing and taking action where appropriate in relation to updates received from the procedural document group.

Clinical Managers (Consultants, Managers and Clinical departmental Managers) are responsible for ensuring that the work performed by the staff they are supervising is performed in accordance with this policy. This follows the usual lines of professional accountability.
Theatre managers are responsible to ensure that all members of the theatre staff adhere to this policy, thereby safeguarding patient safety.
Author is the person who leads on the development or review of a procedural document.
Surgeons are responsible for the return of all equipment used during a surgical procedure to the scrub practitioner.

Scrub Practitioner It is the responsibility of the scrub practitioner to initiate the count and ensure its accuracy and confirming that all equipment is returned after use during a surgical procedure. She/he must be aware of the location of all swabs, needles/blades/equipment/instruments and miscellaneous items at all times during the procedure.
Pertaining to the count

Wherever possible, the team present at the start of a surgical procedure must remain in theatre until that procedure is complete to ensure continuity of patient safety. Should it be necessary to replace the scrub practitioner during a procedure, a full count including instruments must be carried out. The name of the replacement practitioner must be recorded on Sapphire/Nexus.

Where a temporary change is made to the team, a verbal handover must be carried out in reference to what is written on the count board and additions must be noted to ensure continuity of patient safety. All staff in attendance must be recorded on Sapphire/Nexus.
All staff involved in the count must be able to recognize and identify the equipment in use. The following swab, instrument, sharps and miscellaneous disposables checks are mandatory:
An initial count Must be performed before the commencement of a surgical procedure.
A second count Must be performed before the closure of a body cavity within a cavity for ex- ample an organ, before wound closure begins for example, peritoneum.
A final count Must be performed before the closure of skin.
In addition to the above mandatory counts, the scrub practitioner may check the swabs, instruments and sharps at any time he/she deems necessary.
All items must be counted aloud and in unison by the scrub practitioner and checking practitioner in order to prevent any misunderstanding.

A count board must be maintained at all times and must be clearly written. All swabs, sharps and other items must be counted on opening and a running total kept on the count board accurately. See Appendix 1 for full list.

All items removed from the sterile field must be kept in an isolated area within the theatre (bowl and stand). Multiple bags containing used swabs must be visible to the scrub practitioner at all times.
NCEPOD 1

In the event of an NCEPOD 1 immediate life threatening emergency (National Confidential Enquiry into Peri-operative deaths) it is recognised that it is not always feasible to perform an initial, complete count. In these circumstances all packaging must be retained to facilitate a count being undertaken at the earliest and most appropriate opportunity.
A swab and instrument count must be completed when additional bundles of swabs or instruments sets are opened.
Sutures, blades, syringes and all other miscellaneous disposable items must be counted on a running total.
The surgical team must give priority to the count and allow it to be carried out without pressure and interruption.
On completion of the swab and instrument count, the scrub practitioner must inform the surgeon undertaking the procedure and receive verbal acknowledgement in order to eliminate misunderstanding.
Sign Out

On competition of the final swab count at “sign out”, when the whole team engages, a verbal statement must be made by the scrub practitioner to the effect that all swabs, instruments and sharps are accounted for.
Discrepancy

If there is a discrepancy after the count, the scrub practitioner must check the sterile trolley, sterile refuse bag and surrounding areas. If the item is still unaccounted for, the circulating practitioner must check for any missing item: - in the bowl containing items removed from the sterile field during the procedure, the clinical waste bag, recycling and laundry bags. The drapes and floor area must also be searched.

If the item remains unaccounted for, the patient must remain in theatre and an X-ray arranged in the event that the item has been retained inside the patient. In the first instance, a c- arm x-ray may be used. If a missing swab/pledget is not found, a plain x-ray must be ordered. The Floor Person must be informed immediately (see appendix 2 for escalation process).

If the item remains unaccounted after all of the above actions have been completed, this must be recorded by the surgeon in the patient operation record and by the scrub practitioner in the peri-operative care plan and an incident form must be completed. The theatre manager and Governance facilitator must be informed at the earliest convenience.
Items to be retained intentionally

Items which are to remain in the patient by intention (e.g. swabs, packing gauze, drain tubes, catheters) must be recorded in the patient's peri-operative care plan and operation record. The number of items to remain in the patient must also be recorded i.e., in the event of packing/ribbon gauze being divided.

A yellow wrist band must be attached to the patient's wrist when a pack is inserted into any wound. The wrist band must contain details of how many packs are in situ. The only exception is if it is a dissolvable pack.

9.2.1  Bromfield hospital apply an orange wristband is applied to the wrist when a pack is inserted into any wound. The wrist band must contain details of how many packs are in situ. The only exception is if it is a dissolvable pack.
All items including clinical waste, linen and recycle bags must remain in theatre during the case and must not be removed until the end of the case.
Swabs

All swabs must be identified in bundles of 5 and size of swab. Each swab is marked on the board thus: 5+5. If a swab bundle is incorrect at the first count; a second count must be per- formed. If it is still incorrect, the bundle and its wrapping must be removed from theatre completely and a new bundle opened.

The radio-opaque marker on each swab, pack or pledget as well as the integrity of the tapes on abdominal swabs/packs must be identified at every check during a procedure by both staff members. This is to enable traceability during x-ray control in the event of a swab being unaccounted for. Radio- opaque swabs must not be used as a surface wipe.

data.url: MSEPO-21143 Count of swabs, instruments, needles, blades and disposables in theatre.004.png

data.text: For cases where more than 5 swabs are used, a sterile bowl must be opened and placed on a draped bowl stand. Used swabs must be placed into this bowl until 5 have been collected. The circulating practitioner must then receive from the scrub practitioner a bundle of 5 same sized swabs into a clear plastic bag.

Where less than 5 swabs are used, swabs may be kept in a receiver on the trolley and counted from there. If the swabs are from an infected wound or soiled with faecal matter they must not be kept on the trolley but put into a draped sterile bowl.
All X-ray detectable swabs are tied in a red cotton string which must be included as part of the count as an additional measure.

When a bag of swabs has been counted out, the circulating practitioner must then record this on the board at the out section. Bags of used swabs must be placed in view of the scrub practitioner to enable them to see how many swabs have been counted.
All swabs or packs i.e. ribbon gauze inserted to allow secondary healing within cavities must be radio-opaque and accounted for
The anaesthetist may request that the swabs be weighed at any time during the procedure to assist in the assessment of blood loss.
Used pledgets will remain on the trolley in a receptacle. They must be counted out in multiples of 5 into the scrub practitioners sterile refuse bag and marked out on the swab board.
Small and large swabs must be kept separate on the sterile instrument trolley.
On NO account must a swab be cut or wilfully damaged in any way.

All swabs, instruments and sharps and miscellaneous items used in the procedure must be re- moved from the theatre at the end of each case. This includes all laundry and clinical waste containers/bags. All items must be disposed of in the appropriate receptacles in line with Waste Management Policy CM32. In the event of a discrepancy all items remain in theatre for further counting if necessary.
NB: On no account must any item used be returned to the theatre after a case has been completed. The clean bags for the next case must be empty.
Instruments/equipment

All instruments must be visibly checked by the scrub practitioner at the beginning of the case to ensure they are complete and in working order. If not, they must be handed to the circulating practitioner who must send them to SSD for repair at the end of the case.
A visual inspection of instruments and attachments including drill pieces must be carried out when they are returned to the scrub practitioner after use to ensure that they are intact.

Instruments including prosthetic templates must be counted audibly and viewed by both the scrub practitioner and the circulating practitioner. The scrub practitioner must be aware of the location of all equipment/instruments.
All instruments and items with screws or removable parts must be included in the count at the commencement of the surgical procedure.

Instruments including prosthetic templates must be checked against the pre- printed Sterile Services Department (SSD) instrument list before commencement of the procedure. Any discrepancy between the list and instruments present must be recorded on the SSD list. The identification
numbers of the scrub practitioner and circulating practitioner must be recorded on the instrument list.
If the instrument, sharp or disposables is missing and the count is incorrect the surgeon must be informed and all instruments, sharps and disposables must be recounted.
If a blade, needle or instrument breaks during use, the scrub practitioner must ensure that all pieces are returned and accounted for. An incident form must be completed.

Missing micro items (e.g. Needles which cannot be detected on x-ray) must be recorded in the perioperative care plan, and operation sheet. An x-ray should be performed at the discretion of the surgeon. An incident form must be completed and the discrepancy and subsequent action must be reported to the appropriate personnel.
Documentation

On completion of every surgical case the electronic theatre register must be signed by all staff involved in the final count. Any discrepancies must be considered as an untoward incident and an incident form must be completed in accordance with the MSE NHS Foundation Trust formal reporting procedures.
Training requirements

The accountability and responsibility for the swab and instrument count lies with the mentor who must be present at all times until competency has been achieved when training theatre practitioners, student nurses, HCAs, TSWs and newly qualified staff acting as scrub practitioners and circulating staff with supernumerary status. The employment authority is responsible and accountable for the provision of patient care delivered by competent staff.

Students should be given individual training programmes with effective assessment means. This will ensure that practitioners are competent to practice with an appropriate level of understanding of the policy.
Monitoring compliance

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the T&A Divisional Governance Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve MSE/local documents. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the theatre staff of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 3)

National Patient Safety Agency (2009) World Health Organisation Safer Surgical Checklist
Never Events list 2018 - NHS England Never Events list 2018 (updated February 2021) https://www.england.nhs.uk › uploads › 2020/11
Five Steps to Safer Surgery 2020  https://www.afpp.org.uk › filegrab › afpp- chart-4

Detection of retained vaginal swabs and tampons following childbirth https://www.hsib.org.uk › investigations-and-reports (2019)

Risk of harm from retained guide wires following central venous access, 2011, available at http://www.nrls.npsa.nhs.uk/resources/?entryid45=132829 Tracking subsequent removal of intentionally retained swabs, 2011

Standards and recommendations for safe peri-operative practice, 2016, available at http://www.afpp.org.uk/news/safe-practice-highlighted-in-new- afpp-publication Accountable items, swab, instrument and needle count, AfPP 2012, available at http://www.afpp.org.uk/careers/Standards-Guidance

Bulldogs

lahey swabs (pledgets)

Packs
Patties

Slings
Sponges
Tapes

Appendix 2: Unaccounted item post operatively
In the event of there being an item unaccounted for at any stage during surgery, the incident MUST be escalated to the floor person.
Immediate actions:
Surgeon informed
Whole team stop
Theatre searched
All bags
All drapes
Floor/under table/soles of shoes
NB: There is a rolling magnet available in theatres if still unaccounted for:
Inform theatre floor person
Inform theatre manager/Matron
X-ray patient in the operating theatre
Record in patient notes
Complete Incident form
Surgeon to undertake Duty of candour
Escalation process:
Inform floor person
Inform floor consultant
Ophthalmology (Southend/Orsett) Inform Matron/Theatre Manager
Obstetric Theatres Inform Matron/Risk Manager Out of hours
Floor person must inform the site manager
Hand over to Theatre Manager/Matron Theatres at earliest opportunity
